articles.headline: Study Fuels Debate Over Police Lineups
articles.snippet: An experiment in Illinois casts doubt on a new method in which witnesses are shown suspects one at a time.
articles.abstract: An experiment in Illinois casts doubt on a new method in which witnesses are shown suspects one at a time.
articles.lead_paragraph: The police lineup is a time-honored staple of crime solving, not to mention of countless cop movies and television shows like "Law and Order." Each year, experts estimate, 77,000 people nationwide are put on trial because witnesses picked them out of one.

articles.headline: Salads or No, Cheap Burgers Revive McDonald's
articles.snippet: The turnaround has come not from greater sales of healthy foods but from selling more fast-food basics.
articles.abstract: The turnaround has come not from greater sales of healthy foods but from selling more fast-food basics.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon at McDonald's in Union Square in Manhattan, Chris Rivera and Shamell Jackson reviewed the menu, which includes a variety of healthy options, including salad and fruit. Then they each ordered the usual: two McChicken sandwiches from the Dollar Menu, fries and a McFlurry shake.

articles.headline: China's Oil Needs Are High on U.S. Agenda
articles.snippet: China's oil demand, which the U.S. has blamed in part for rising prices, will be a subject of President Hu Jintao's visit.
articles.abstract: China's oil demand, which the U.S. has blamed in part for rising prices, will be a subject of President Hu Jintao's visit.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 18 â€” The competition for access to oil is emerging high on the agenda for President Hu Jintao's visit to the White House this week. President Bush has called China's growing demand for oil one reason for rising prices, and has warned Beijing against trying to "lock up" global supplies.

articles.headline: Study Fuels Debate Over Police Lineups
articles.snippet: The police lineup is a time-honored staple of crime solving, not to mention of countless cop movies and television shows like ''Law and Order.'' Each year, experts estimate, 77,000 people nationwide are put on trial because witnesses picked them o...
articles.abstract: The police lineup is a time-honored staple of crime solving, not to mention of countless cop movies and television shows like ''Law and Order.'' Each year, experts estimate, 77,000 people nationwide are put on trial because witnesses picked them out of one.     In recent years many states and cities have moved to overhaul lineups, as DNA evidence has exposed nearly 200 wrongful convictions, three-quarters of them resulting primarily from bad eyewitness identification.
articles.lead_paragraph: The police lineup is a time-honored staple of crime solving, not to mention of countless cop movies and television shows like "Law and Order." Each year, experts estimate, 77,000 people nationwide are put on trial because witnesses picked them out of one.

articles.headline: Yahoo Profit Falls 22%; Ad Sales Up
articles.snippet: Yahoo reported a 22 percent decline in first-quarter profit on Tuesday but met Wall Street's earnings forecast, helped by solid growth in advertising sales.     As a result, Yahoo's shares rose $1.92, or 6.1 percent, in after-hours trading, after ...
articles.abstract: Yahoo reported a 22 percent decline in first-quarter profit on Tuesday but met Wall Street's earnings forecast, helped by solid growth in advertising sales.     As a result, Yahoo's shares rose $1.92, or 6.1 percent, in after-hours trading, after closing up 33 cents, at $31.30, in the regular session.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, April 18 - Yahoo reported a 22 percent decline in first-quarter profit on Tuesday but met Wall Street's earnings forecast, helped by solid growth in advertising sales.

articles.headline: Fed Signals Policy Shift on Rates
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve hinted Tuesday that it might stop its campaign to raise interest rates as early as next month, a possibility that set off a surge in stocks even as crude oil prices rose above $71 a barrel.     According to a summary released T...
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve hinted Tuesday that it might stop its campaign to raise interest rates as early as next month, a possibility that set off a surge in stocks even as crude oil prices rose above $71 a barrel.     According to a summary released Tuesday of the Fed's policy-setting Federal Open Markets Committee meeting in late March, ''most members thought that the end of the tightening process was likely to be near, and some expressed concerns about the dangers of tightening too much.''
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 18 - The Federal Reserve hinted Tuesday that it might stop its campaign to raise interest rates as early as next month, a possibility that set off a surge in stocks even as crude oil prices rose above $71 a barrel.

articles.headline: Salads or No, Cheap Burgers Revive McDonald's
articles.snippet: On a recent afternoon at McDonald's in Union Square in Manhattan, Chris Rivera and Shamell Jackson reviewed the menu, which includes a variety of healthy options, including salad and fruit. Then they each ordered the usual: two McChicken sandwiche...
articles.abstract: On a recent afternoon at McDonald's in Union Square in Manhattan, Chris Rivera and Shamell Jackson reviewed the menu, which includes a variety of healthy options, including salad and fruit. Then they each ordered the usual: two McChicken sandwiches from the Dollar Menu, fries and a McFlurry shake.      The two 15-year-olds, like many of their classmates at the nearby Washington Irving High School, go to McDonald's often. And it is customers like Mr. Jackson and Ms. Rivera, consistently ordering the cheaper and more fattening items on the menu, who have fueled a remarkable resurgence at McDonald's.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon at McDonald's in Union Square in Manhattan, Chris Rivera and Shamell Jackson reviewed the menu, which includes a variety of healthy options, including salad and fruit. Then they each ordered the usual: two McChicken sandwiches from the Dollar Menu, fries and a McFlurry shake.

articles.headline: F.B.I. Is Seeking to Search Papers of Dead Reporter
articles.snippet: The F.B.I. is seeking to go through the files of the late newspaper columnist Jack Anderson to remove classified material he may have accumulated in four decades of muckraking Washington journalism.     Mr. Anderson's family has refused to allow a...
articles.abstract: The F.B.I. is seeking to go through the files of the late newspaper columnist Jack Anderson to remove classified material he may have accumulated in four decades of muckraking Washington journalism.     Mr. Anderson's family has refused to allow a search of 188 boxes, the files of a well-known reporter who had long feuded with the Federal Bureau of Investigation and had exposed plans by the Central Intelligence Agency to kill Fidel Castro, the machinations of the Iran-contra affair and the misdemeanors of generations of congressmen.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 18 - The F.B.I. is seeking to go through the files of the late newspaper columnist Jack Anderson to remove classified material he may have accumulated in four decades of muckraking Washington journalism.

articles.headline: Benefits Threatened, Auto Workers Line Up for Elective Procedures
articles.snippet: The auto industry's efforts to rein in employee health costs is drawing an expensive reaction, as union workers and their spouses hurry to Michigan doctors for knee replacements and other elective procedures before they lose their comprehensive me...
articles.abstract: The auto industry's efforts to rein in employee health costs is drawing an expensive reaction, as union workers and their spouses hurry to Michigan doctors for knee replacements and other elective procedures before they lose their comprehensive medical benefits.      Hospitals, doctors and insurers have all noticed a surge in demand for elective surgery since last year when Rick Wagoner, the chief executive of General Motors, led a public relations campaign to prepare auto workers for health care cutbacks, and Delphi, the G.M. parts supplier, filed for bankruptcy protection. Hip, knee and shoulder replacements at the Henry Ford Health System were ''up 20 percent in the second half of last year and remain strong,'' said Robert Riney, chief operating officer of the system, the largest hospital group in the Detroit area.

articles.headline: Here's Donny! In His Defense, a Show Is Born
articles.snippet: It has become a daily ritual, the defense of the defense secretary, complete with praise from serving generals, tributes from the president and, from the man on the spot, doses of charm, combativeness and even some humility.     A session on Tuesd...
articles.abstract: It has become a daily ritual, the defense of the defense secretary, complete with praise from serving generals, tributes from the president and, from the man on the spot, doses of charm, combativeness and even some humility.     A session on Tuesday was the third time in five days that Donald H. Rumsfeld had sought to make a public case to remain as defense secretary.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 18 - It has become a daily ritual, the defense of the defense secretary, complete with praise from serving generals, tributes from the president and, from the man on the spot, doses of charm, combativeness and even some humility.

articles.headline: Political Clout in the Age of Outsourcing
articles.snippet: A FEW years ago, stories about a scary new kind of outsourcing began making the rounds. Apparently, hospitals were starting to send their radiology work to India, where doctors who make far less than American radiologists do were reading X-rays, M...
articles.abstract: A FEW years ago, stories about a scary new kind of outsourcing began making the rounds. Apparently, hospitals were starting to send their radiology work to India, where doctors who make far less than American radiologists do were reading X-rays, M.R.I.'s and CT scans.      It quickly became a signature example of how globalization was moving up the food chain, threatening not just factory and call center workers but the so-called knowledge workers who were supposed to be immune. If radiologists and their $350,000 average salaries weren't safe from the jobs exodus, who was?
articles.lead_paragraph: A FEW years ago, stories about a scary new kind of outsourcing began making the rounds. Apparently, hospitals were starting to send their radiology work to India, where doctors who make far less than American radiologists do were reading X-rays, M.R.I.'s and CT scans.

articles.headline: The Calculus of Taking the Buyout
articles.snippet: Consciously or not, the tens of thousands of General Motors workers who face decisions about the company's buyout offers before an early June deadline are getting a crash course in medical cost-benefit analysis.      The prospect of losing General...
articles.abstract: Consciously or not, the tens of thousands of General Motors workers who face decisions about the company's buyout offers before an early June deadline are getting a crash course in medical cost-benefit analysis.      The prospect of losing General Motors health coverage can be terrifying for workers who went straight from high school into factory jobs and have few good prospects for employment beyond the assembly line.
articles.lead_paragraph: Consciously or not, the tens of thousands of General Motors workers who face decisions about the company's buyout offers before an early June deadline are getting a crash course in medical cost-benefit analysis.

articles.headline: S.E.C. Panel to Urge Auditing Exceptions
articles.snippet: An influential advisory committee appointed by the Securities and Exchange Commission is about to formally propose that thousands of smaller companies be exempted from significant parts of the four-year-old law that imposed significant new auditin...
articles.abstract: An influential advisory committee appointed by the Securities and Exchange Commission is about to formally propose that thousands of smaller companies be exempted from significant parts of the four-year-old law that imposed significant new auditing rules on corporate America.     But the advisory committee's leader, Herbert S. Wander, has had his own recent experience with audit problems. He has served for many years on the board and on the audit committee of a publicly traded company that in recent months has disclosed a steady stream of significant accounting lapses.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 18 - An influential advisory committee appointed by the Securities and Exchange Commission is about to formally propose that thousands of smaller companies be exempted from significant parts of the four-year-old law that imposed significant new auditing rules on corporate America.

articles.headline: China's Oil Needs Are High on U.S. Agenda
articles.snippet: The competition for access to oil is emerging high on the agenda for President Hu Jintao's visit to the White House this week. President Bush has called China's growing demand for oil one reason for rising prices, and has warned Beijing against tr...
articles.abstract: The competition for access to oil is emerging high on the agenda for President Hu Jintao's visit to the White House this week. President Bush has called China's growing demand for oil one reason for rising prices, and has warned Beijing against trying to ''lock up'' global supplies.     With crude oil selling for more than $70 a barrel and American motorists paying $3 a gallon for gasoline, American officials say the subject cannot be avoided at Thursday's meeting in the Oval Office, as it was sidestepped when Mr. Bush visited Beijing last fall.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 18 - The competition for access to oil is emerging high on the agenda for President Hu Jintao's visit to the White House this week. President Bush has called China's growing demand for oil one reason for rising prices, and has warned Beijing against trying to "lock up" global supplies.
